Wandering loanword = Wanderwort ⋍
Cultural trade word = Kulturwort

Wanderwort

«A word that was spread among numerous languages and cultures, usually
in connection with trade, so that it becomes impossible to establish its
original etymology, or even its original language.»
-- Wikipedia 18 Febr. 2007

Wonderwards ;) PSM

Due to it's 3000 year prevalence, Egyptian was central in the distribution of Wanderwords.
In fact most known ancient Wanderwords have a representative in the Egyptian language, and many words in the Egyptian language are themselves super-regional words, connected to wide-spread and well known word-clusters.

Wandersigns

Wandersigns are wanderworts with near identical phonetic value that are connected to near identical stable signs.

Theses astonishing clusters can probably be explained by the advent and spread of syllabic writing, where some signs were adopted and learned as axioms even when they were foreign to local languages, one academic example being 𔒴 nu ≈ 𜎜 nu ≈ 𐊵 N ≈ 𐀛 ni 𐘝 NI νικύλεον "fig" of unknown origin.

By far the best examples in the history of syllabic writing are:

𒆳 kur 𒆠 ki 𔗜 ku 𜐺 KU 𐘾 ka 𐀏 KA 𑁣 керла 𔕆 •KAR 𔕈 KA 𔕇 𐀤 𐘿 QE 𒉽 KUR₂ 𒄯 Ḫar 𓊖 [1]
𜰸 𓊖 𜰴 𒆠 KAR KIʳ IDENTICAL continuum in Indus Valley Harappan script !!!
The surface features Kreuz and Kreis (cross and circle) or Kreuz and Karos (cross and squares) only reveal the underlying wanderword(s) to ones familiar with the script: In at least three instances of remote regions Egypt, Elam, Sumer, Indus and Anatolia these signs mean "city" or country. See KAR for exhaustive discussion.

One "wandersyllable" PA… is connected to a kind of wanderwort which has only one Wandersign representative:

𓃀𓂾 pod/Bein pair ( unless 𒉺 = 𐘂 = 𐀞 ≈ 𐎔 ≈ 𒋰 was understood as 𓃀𓃀 in some cirles )

some prominent examples are:

nurma “pomegranate” wanderword

𒉡𒌫𒈠 NU-UR2-MA /nurmû/ nurma "pomegranate" Sumerian
𒉡𒊑𒅎𒁺 (nu-ri-im-du /nurimdu, nurimtu/, “pomegranate” Akkadian
𒉡𒊏𒀭𒋾 (nu-ra-an-ti /nuranti/, “pomegranate” Hurrian => Armenian նուռն (nuṙn) նուռ (hy) (nuṙ)
𒉡𒊏𒋾 (/nurati-/) “pomegranate” Hittite Persian نار nâr انار anâr анар ھەنار henar अनार anār 榴 m·ru OC
𒉡𒌫𒈠 nurma ⇔ Akkadian 𒄑𒈢𒆳𒊏 /armannu/ ሩማን (ruman), ሮማን (roman) رُمَّان m (rummān) רימון \ רִמּוֹן (rimmṓn), Punic *𐤓𐤌𐤍 (rmn /rimmūn/) and Aramaic רִימֹּונָא / רִמֹּונָא (rimmōnā) / רוּמָּנָא / ܪܘܡܢܐ (rummānā)
𒉡 𒌫𒈠 nurma ⇔ Akkadian 𒇻𒆸𒌅 (/lurmû, lurimtu, lurinnu/, “pomegranate” Ugaritic 𐎍𐎗𐎎𐎐 (lrmn, “pomegranate”
𓈖 𓉔 𓏮 𓌴 𓁹 𓄿 𓄿 𓈒 𓏥 | pomegranate | ⋍ nHmair > 𐎍𐎗𐎎𐎐 (lrmn, “pomegranate” ⲗⲉϩⲙⲉⲛ (lehmen) ⇔ lemon, ᴺorange
𓇋 𓈖 𓉔 𓏠 𓆭 | pomegranate (tree and fruit) | #jnhmn > ϩⲉⲣⲙⲁⲛ (herman, Sahidic) ⲉⲣⲙⲁⲛ (erman, Bohairic) Demotic hrnt
𓇋 𓆛 𓈖 𓉔 𓅓 𓂝 𓈖 𓏮 𓆭 | pomegranate (tree and fruit) | (jnhmn /alhammān/)

𓂓 𓏤 𓅷 𓏤 𓍘 𓇋 𓍱 𓏪 ⲕⲟⲩⲫⲁⲧ carpet ⲩ √ⲫⲁⲧ 𓃀 կարպետ karpet կապերտ kapert ਕਾਰਪੇਟ kārpeṭ ᠬᠡᠪᠢᠰ kebis кевс •capis tapis

𒆠𒍇 Tüchtigkeit Tech (business) туька tykə
𒆠𒍇 shop: دُكَّان dukkān dükan دکان dokân дюкя́н djukján দোকান (dükan) दुकान dukān туька tüka ду̀ћа̄н dùćān Tuktuk
𒆠𒍇 = 𓍿 𓅱 𓊍 ⇔ 𓏏 𓈖 𓅷 𓊎 𓏏 𓏤

𓈗 MAR wanderword 𒈨𒊏𒉡 me-ra-nu "bitter" @ marine մռու mṙuⁿ መራራ märara 𐎎𐎗 mr مُرّ murr mürr amargu amur amuor marcus mõru 𒈨𒊏𒉡 me-ra-nu amarᵒⁿ amārus@Latin מַר mar מרה mará מָרִיר marír מרירה amargo მწარე mc̣are ! ຂົມ khom? mapait?

"One of the characteristics of these
modern wandering words is that we can observe them rapidly spreading
across Europe and beyond, and through many languages. They have had
little time to undergo language-specific developments, and this is why the
precise route of their wanderings is sometimes so difficult to trace: we
have no sound-laws to guide us."

Later products, Wanderworts after the pharaos
ginger
cumin
soap
meter (maß)
green tea (not yet)

mine 𐎎𐎐 mn μνᾶ mina مَنْجَم manjam

An alternative denomination for these kinds of words is
internationalisms, although some prefer to reserve the latter term for
technical innovations from the 19 th and 20 th century only, such as
telephone, automobile and computer.

Suggested measurements:

Wanderworthyness shall be a weighted sum of these sub-heuristics:

Percentage of main word usage near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of main word usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of main word usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot

Because of increased leeway the last categories should be weighted lowly and/or treated carefully.

pod(leg)⇔boot⇔foot

want უნდა undɑ

See also persistently preserved words

Moth

Moth has a wanderwort with trajectory leading to •k't with duplication on either side

𒊓𒋢 sa-su | moth | σής sḗs סָס sas цӏецӏ c̣ec̣ ցեց cʿecʿ עָשׁ ˠash ˠvešča couza ಚಿಟ್ಟೆ ciṭṭe kode عُثَّة ʿuṯṯa
𒊓𒋢 sa-su | moth | σής sḗs ciṭṭe gegat kode көйә köyä güvə 蛾 がー gā 蛾 é
𒊓𒋢 sa-su | moth | σής sḗs цӏецӏ c̣ec̣ ჩრჩილი črčili
𒊓𒋢 sa-su | moth | gegat / ciṭṭe + moth => សត្វខ្មូត sɑɑtvɔɔkmuut

maʿuṯṯa => Motte => moth ⇔ 𐌼𐌰𐌻𐍉 ⇔ ϩⲟⲗⲓ

ʿuṯṯa ⇔ butterfly Schmetterling

Some wanderworts might hint at genetic relationship in flow models of Good-Linguistics

Perser Pfirsich peach fruit apricot / ᵍArmenian

𒅈𒌋𒌋𒉡 ar-man-nu 𓄿𓃭𓆲𓇋𓇋𓈖𓄿 ꜣrmꜥynꜣ ἀρμενιακόν armeniakón +++
